title-group.subtitle: Report of a Case and Review of the Literature

article-meta.aff: 2Hospital San Juan de Dios, San José, Costa Rica

author-notes.corresp: Francesca Giunchi, Department of Pathology, University of Bologna, Via Zamboni, 33-40126 Bologna, Italy Email: frachikka@virgilio.it

abstract.p: We describe a rare case of malignant teratoma involving the entire right lung. A 28 years old man was admitted to the hospital with severe respiratory failure and general malaise. Chest X-ray showed a dense opacity of the entire right lung, accompanied by pleural effusion. At autopsy, the right lung was completed replaced by a mass of variegated appearance combining cystic spaces and solid areas. Microscopically, the lung tumor exhibited a polymorphous histological picture. Most of the tissue had a malignant mesenchymal appearance, which included areas of chondrosarcoma, chondroblastic osteosarcoma, well differentiated liposarcoma, and undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma. Other areas of the tumor showed malignant epithelial components consistent with bronchial and urothelial mucosa with also scattered islands of pigmented epithelium of probable neuronal or retinal nature.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Teratoma is a common tumor of the mediastinum, but primary malignant teratoma of the lung is exceptionally rare.1 To substantiate the diagnosis, one has to exclude the most likely alternative of a lung metastasis or direct extension from a teratoma arisen in another site, particularly testis, mediastinum, and retroperitoneum.2
We report here a case of primary malignant teratoma of the right lung in a 28-year-old man that filled out the entire right thoracic cavity.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 28-year-old man was admitted to the hospital with severe respiratory failure and general malaise. Chest X-ray showed a dense opacity of the entire right lung (Figure 1), accompanied by pleural effusion. Pleural fluid obtained at thoracocentesis was negative for malignant cells. This was followed by a biopsy through a small thoracotomy, which was interpreted as consistent with a malignant teratoma.

caption.p: Chest X-ray showing the tumor opacity involving the entire right lung

sec.p: Clinicoradiographic examination of testes, mediastinum, and retroperitoneum showed no abnormalities. Whole-body computed tomography confirmed the presence of a large right lung tumor but did not reveal other lesions elsewhere.
The patient’s condition rapidly deteriorated, and he died a few days after admission.

At autopsy, it was seen that the right lung was completely replaced by a mass of variegated appearance combining cystic spaces and solid areas (Figure 2). The hilar lymph nodes and the left lung were normal. There was no evidence of tumor or other lesions in the testis, mediastinum, or retroperitoneum.

caption.p: Coronal section of the involved right lung and the normal left lung

sec.p: Microscopically, the lung tumor exhibited a polymorphous histological picture. Most of the tissue had a malignant mesenchymal appearance, which included areas of chondrosarcoma, chondroblastic osteosarcoma, well-differentiated liposarcoma, and undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma. Aspects of vascular tumor and rhabdomyosarcoma were presented (Figure 3).

caption.p: (A) Rhabdomiosarcomartous features; (B) pleomorphic aspects of the sarcomatoid component; (C) well-differentiated liposarcoma; (D and E) 2 different views of the chondrosarcomatous component; (F) angiomatous pattern

sec.p: Other areas of the tumor showed malignant epithelial components consistent with bronchial and urothelial mucosa. There were also scattered islands of pigmented epithelium of probable neuronal or retinal nature (Figure 4).

caption.p: (A) Mature component of the tumor in the middle of chondrosarcoma; (B) benign epithelium; (C) pigmented epithelium

sec.p: Microscopic examination of both testicles and all other organs showed no evidence of tumor or other significant abnormalities.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Primary malignant teratoma of the lung is an extremely rare condition. To the best of our knowledge, only 8 cases have been published so far (Table 1). All these patients had by definition a tumor located in the lung with no evidence of an extrapulmonary source. The origin of this tumor is not clear, but it has been suggested that it is anatomically related to the thymus. According to this theory, in early embryo the primordial teratomatous focus originally located in the thymus may lie in such a position in the potential mediastinum that it is caught up and carried by the respiratory outgrowth from the foregut.3 Most teratomas occurred in the left upper lobe, but the exact reason for this predominance was not known, particularly whether it was associated or not with the histogenesis of the tumor.9 In fact, 5 of the reported cases of intrapulmonary teratoma were located in the upper lobe of the left and right lung, and only 2 were in the lower lobes. All patients were male, of wide-ranging ages.

sec.p: Most of the patients were adults.2,4 Only 1 case has been described in an infant (10-month old)5 and another in a child (12 years).6-9 In none of the previously reported cases was there involvement of the entire lung, as it happened in our case.

The prognosis was generally poor, with death usually occurring days or months after presentation. Only 2 cases were associated with a good prognosis after surgical excision, with no evidence of recurrence at the time of the last follow-up.6,9 One patient was treated with a combination of radiation therapy and chemotherapy but with poor results: The disease spread widely to the other lobe and recurred on the same side.1 Evaluation of the reported cases suggests that postoperative radiation therapy should be used if there is residual disease or nodal metastasis, whereas preoperative radiation therapy should be considered if there is evidence of chest wall involvement.9

In 2 cases the tumor presented with regional lymph node metastasis, associated in 1 case with vein and lymph vessels dissemination.5,9 The other cases, including ours, presented with a single, well-demarcated mass involving an entire lung or part of it. It has been pointed out that this tumor type has a prognosis similar to that of lung carcinoma, with a tendency for metastases to occur in association with the epithelial component of the tumor.9 Indeed, 2 of the 3 cases associated with lymph node dissemination had an epithelial component in the primary tumor.

In summary, we describe a case of malignant teratoma apparently primary in the lung characterized by a very rapid growth rate and the variegated morphologic appearance that typifies teratomas in general.
